Violation_Type: Failure to recognize personalized risk under IRPA
Application_Facts: Tomlinson was targeted due to his brother's actions against a gang, resulting in specific threats and attacks; the Board incorrectly classified the risk as generalized based on Jamaica's crime rates.
Procedural_Issue: Board's erroneous characterization of risk; case remanded for re-determination by a different panel
Evidence_Used: Threats and attacks linked to gang retaliation; brother's police work
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to properly assess individualized risk despite evidence of targeted violence
Relief_Sought: Recognition of personalized risk and refugee protection
Remedy_Sought: Remand for re-determination by a different Board panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of IRPA – personalized risk not shared by the general population
Decision_Rationale: Tomlinson faced a specific, personal risk due to familial association with a police officer who acted against a gang, which is distinct from generalized violence in Jamaica.

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of removal officer's decision to deny deferral of removal
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: Conflicting medical evidence regarding the male applicant's health
Decision_Outcome: Removal officer's decision found unreasonable and set aside
Credibility_Factor: Unresolved controversy over medical condition due to lack of disclosure
Legal_Rule: Section 48(2) of IRPA requires removal to be 'reasonably practicable'
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness simpliciter for mixed questions of law and fact
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to disclose evidence, improper H&C analysis outside proper forum
Outcome_on_Merits: Decision deemed untenable and made in reviewable error
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical reports on applicant's health status
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Act, IRPA, principles of administrative fairness
Defendant_Response: Removal officer denied deferral without full procedural fairness
Remedy_Requested: Deferral of removal pending H&C application decision
Outcome: Decision set aside; remanded for re-determination after H&C decision

Legal_Issue: Whether 'LIGHTRECYCLE & DESIGN' is clearly descriptive under s. 12(1)(b) of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: New evidence was considered; court found Registrar's analysis unreasonable due to multiple interpretations of 'light' and lack of justification for prioritizing word over design
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant (Product Care Association) to demonstrate registrability
Credibility_Factor: Registrar's reasoning deemed unreasonable by court
Legal_Rule: A trademark is not registrable if it is clearly descriptive of the goods or services (s. 12(1)(b))
Grounds_for_Claim: Trademark 'LIGHTRECYCLE & DESIGN' is clearly descriptive of recycling services for light-related products
Outcome_on_Merits: Trademark not registrable as it is clearly descriptive
Key_Evidence_Considered: Meaning and interpretation of 'light', presence of design element in mark
Defendant_Response: Registrar rejected registration; upheld on appeal with revised reasoning
Remedy_Requested: Registration of 'LIGHTRECYCLE & DESIGN' as a trademark

Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistent testimony leading to negative credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: RPD must consider all evidence, including independent documentation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of persecution due to ethnic and physical profile in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Profile as a scarred Tamil male linked to state targeting
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant denied credibility due to inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary country evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of RPD decision and re-hearing
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed, matter returned for reconsideration

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD made an unreasonable credibility determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to inconsistencies in testimony and documentation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence on risks to scarred Tamil males
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Past persecution and future risk due to visible scars
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to assess forward-looking risk based on physical profile
Crimes.Application_Error: Overreliance on credibility without assessing objective risk
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of credibility and risk assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Country condition evidence related to treatment of scarred Tamil males
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk of harm
Crimes.Application_Factor: Possession of forged documents affecting credibility
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Possession of forged identity or travel documents

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD failed to consider credible evidence and made an unreasonable credibility finding
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible due to inconsistencies (e.g., sister’s location, work history)
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Independent documentary evidence on risks to scarred Tamil males
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to ethnic identity and physical scarring
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to assess future risk despite discredited testimony
Crimes.Application_Error: Did not assess forward-looking risk based on applicant profile
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Justification, transparency, and intelligibility of decision
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Documentary evidence about state surveillance and detention of scarred Tamil males
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of false passport undermining credibility
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of false passport for entry into Canada

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving allegations of human smuggling
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to properly assess available evidence despite credibility concerns
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Independent documentary evidence available but not considered
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Irregular entry with assistance of third party
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No explicit criminal record, but credibility issues raised
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Potential involvement in organized criminal activity
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Risk upon return due to profile as a scarred Tamil male from Sri Lanka
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Country condition reports and expert documentation
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed, decision quashed, matter remanded
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Failure to assess forward-looking risk despite negative credibility
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee protection and admissibility provisions under IRPA
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to consider relevant evidence impacting risk assessment

Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant's motion for an extension of time to file for judicial review can be granted under s. 82.1(5) of the Immigration Act
Procedural_Stage: Motion for extension of time; Judicial review application
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient details provided about conviction or Minister's decision; reliance on solicitor's affidavit instead of personal testimony
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to meet burden by not showing special reasons or good case on the merits
Credibility_Factor: Lack of personal affidavit from applicant affects credibility
Legal_Rule: Section 82.1(5) requires 'special reasons', a good case on the merits, and procedural compliance for extension
Grounds_for_Claim: Extension of time beyond 15-day limit for filing judicial review
Outcome_on_Merits: No determination made due to procedural deficiencies
Legal_Framework: Immigration and refugee protection law; procedural rules for judicial review
Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to file for leave and judicial review
Outcome: Motion dismissed; originating motion for leave and judicial review denied

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose criminal conviction in immigration documents
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's exclusion analysis under Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to disclose prior conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal conviction record, immigration application documents
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Prior fraud conviction not disclosed in immigration documents
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to consider low actual sentence and wide Canadian sentencing range
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Seriousness based on international norms and domestic sentencing practices
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Mitigating factors, actual sentence served (165 days)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Presumption of seriousness rebuttable by context
Crimes.Application_Factor: Maximum sentence in Canada (14 years) vs. actual sentence imposed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted for redetermination by a different panel

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant convicted of fraud in Korea prior to seeking refugee status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to conduct contextual assessment of crime seriousness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Application of Canadian sentencing norms to foreign conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Foreign conviction record, Canadian equivalent sentencing provisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis of mitigating circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undermined due to nondisclosure
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Presumption of seriousness if punishable by 10+ years in Canada
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Need for contextual analysis despite presumptive seriousness

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection based on seriousness of prior crime
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board reasonably applied Article 1F(b) exclusion
Crimes.Governing_Law: Article 1F(b), Refugee Convention; Canadian Criminal Code (fraud over $5,000)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Consideration of Korean conviction and Canadian sentencing equivalence
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the state to prove seriousness for exclusion
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Non-disclosure affects credibility but does not automatically establish seriousness
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A crime with maximum 10+ year sentence is presumptively serious but rebuttable
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Error in failing to assess mitigating factors and low end of sentencing range
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Actual sentence (10 months, 165 days served), nature of fraud
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law and domestic analogues
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Foreign judgment, expert or legal comparison of sentencing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 380(1)(a) of the Criminal Code (fraud over $5,000); Article 1F(b)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's assessment of H&C grounds under s. 25 IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer focused on misrepresentation but failed to assess broader credibility in context of H&C factors
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application records, family status documents, declarations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to declare dependents leading to inadmissibility
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Overemphasis on misrepresentation, insufficient consideration of children's best interests and family reunification
Crimes.Application_Error: Narrow focus on misrepresentation and status quo
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential for family reunification in Canada, best interests of children in Canadian context
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under s. 25 IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Family ties in Canada, best interests of the child
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted for redetermination by another officer
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False declaration regarding dependents on immigration documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to declare dependants in application for permanent residence
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility due to omission in sponsorship application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of officer’s evaluation of H&C factors, particularly best interests of children
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 25 and s. 117(9)(d) of the IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessment based on conditions in Bangladesh without full comparison to life in Canada
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, remitted for reassessment
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compelling H&C grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Sponsor’s failure to disclose marital status and children upon arrival
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Best interests of the child must be a primary consideration in H&C assessment
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Exclusion from family class due to non-disclosure of dependents
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Children’s current living conditions, potential for family unity in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and compassionate provisions under IRPA
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Emphasis on compliance with immigration rules and prior misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Family documentation, affidavits, country condition reports
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Redetermination of H&C application by a different officer

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility based on misrepresentation and H&C assessment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether officer reasonably assessed humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s husband misrepresented marital status and dependent information
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration forms, supporting documents, declarations of family members
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation leading to inadmissibility under immigration rules
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Overemphasis on misrepresentation, lack of holistic H&C analysis
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider family reunification and children's best interests in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Positive H&C factors including integration potential and family ties in Canada
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of time in Canada, impact on children, stability of family unit
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reassessment by another officer
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False or incomplete information in immigration application regarding dependents

Legal_Issue: Whether Genpharm's allegations of invalidity and non-infringement are justified
Evidence_Assessment: Analysis of prior art, product formulation, expert opinions, inventive step
Burden_of_Proof: On generic manufacturer (Genpharm) to substantiate invalidity or non-infringement
Credibility_Factor: Strength of AstraZeneca's evidence on inventive step and specific use
Legal_Rule: Generic must provide detailed statement of legal and factual basis for invalidity/non-infringement claims
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness of allegations based on evidence and law
Grounds_for_Claim: Prior art, differences in formulation, alleged lack of novelty/inventive step
Outcome_on_Merits: AstraZeneca succeeded; patents upheld as valid and potentially infringed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Patents '693, '377, '668, '762, expert testimony, prior art references
Defendant_Response: Genpharm challenged validity and infringement of AstraZeneca's patents
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, expert reports, patent specifications
Remedy_Requested: Order prohibiting issuance of NOC to Genpharm
Outcome: Order granted; NOC prohibited until patent expiration
Legal_Provision: Sections under the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations

Risk_Assessment: Material change in situation not proven
Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to prove inadequate state protection
Evidence_Credibility: Not convincing regarding material change or future risk
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evidence not sufficiently credible to rebut presumption

Dispute_Type: Patent validity and infringement under regulatory framework
Legal_Issue: Whether Genpharm's manufacturing and selling of citalopram infringes Lundbeck's '368 patent
Procedural_Stage: Application to prohibit issuance of Notice of Compliance
Evidence_Assessment: Expert evidence showed citalopram is used for depression, with insufficient proof of use in dementia or cerebrovascular disorders
Burden_of_Proof: On generic manufacturer to prove non-infringement under PM (NOC) Regulations
Credibility_Factor: Credibility of expert evidence on medical uses of citalopram
Legal_Rule: Generic must prove non-infringement of listed patents; court evaluates justification based on evidence
Standard_of_Review: Justification of allegations based on evidentiary record
Grounds_for_Claim: Lundbeck claimed potential use overlap in dementia/CVD treatment
Outcome_on_Merits: Genpharm's allegation of non-infringement was justified
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical evidence on approved and intended use of citalopram
Legal_Framework: Regulatory approval process under PM (NOC) Regulations
Defendant_Response: Genpharm limited indication to depression and denied intent to treat patented conditions
Evidence_Type: Expert testimony, product labeling, clinical data
Remedy_Requested: Injunction to prevent Health Canada from issuing Notice of Compliance
Outcome: Application denied; Genpharm allowed to proceed
Legal_Provision: Section under PM (NOC) Regulations regarding patent listing and certification

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide parties with opportunity to present submissions on release terms
Outcome: Matter referred back for redetermination by a different officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness, right to be heard
Decision_Rationale: Member made significant changes to conditions not requested or argued by either party

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of organized criminality
Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Member failed to allow parties to present submissions on release terms
Outcome: Matter referred back for redetermination by a different officer
Basis_for_Decision: Alteration of release conditions without input
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Changes made without party input or request

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with the recognizance
Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in amending release conditions
Legal_Rule: Parties must have opportunity to be heard

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in modifying release conditions
Legal_Rule: Right to be heard before changes to release conditions
Grounds_for_Claim: Unilateral changes by Member without submissions
Outcome: Decision overturned and matter referred back

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to allow submissions on amended release conditions
Basis_for_Decision: Unauthorized changes to conditions beyond scope of request
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Altered conditions without notice or argument from parties

Legal_Issue: Registrability of the trademark 'Deli Snack' under the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of consumer perception and contextual use of the term 'Deli Snack'
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant (Neptune S.A.) to demonstrate registrability
Legal_Rule: A trademark is not registrable if it is clearly descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive of the character or quality of the goods
Grounds_for_Claim: The trademark 'Deli Snack' is descriptive of seafood-based snacks
Outcome_on_Merits: The claim for registration was rejected on substantive grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Meaning and common usage of 'Deli Snack' in relation to delicatessen snack foods
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-marks Act and administrative review principles
Defendant_Response: Registrar opposed registration on grounds of descriptiveness
Evidence_Type: Descriptive meaning of words, market context, consumer understanding

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer erred in refusing the temporary resident visa application
Evidence_Assessment: The officer dismissed the application based on perceived weak family ties and insufficient financial resources, despite substantial evidence provided by the applicants
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate intent to leave Canada and meet admissibility requirements
Credibility_Factor: Applicants provided evidence of financial stability and familial ties
Legal_Rule: Under IRPA and its regulations, a visa can be issued if the officer is satisfied that the foreign national will leave Canada by the end of their authorized stay and meets other requirements
Grounds_for_Claim: Errors in decision-making process, including failure to consider relevant evidence
Outcome_on_Merits: The Federal Court found the decision unreasonable due to inadequate reasoning
Key_Evidence_Considered: Financial stability, familial ties in home country
Defendant_Response: Visa officer maintained refusal based on weak ties and finances
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of financial status and family connections
Outcome: Court allowed judicial review and remitted the matter for redetermination by a different visa officer

Application_Facts: Discrepancies in applicant's statements raised concerns about candour; ancillary factors such as funding sources and family details informed the decision.
Misrepresentation_Element: Perceived lack of candour, incomplete background information
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness; no breach found as applicant was aware of the issues
Evidence_Used: Applicant's statements, funding sources, family details
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility assessment due to lack of candour
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for factual assessments, correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Decision was reasonable; no breach of procedural fairness occurred

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on lack of durable solution prospects
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants fled Sierra Leone's civil war and applied for permanent residence but were found inadmissible due to involvement with the Civil Defense Unit
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer did not assess compelling reasons exception under section 108(4)
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Finding of no reasonable prospect of durable solutions elsewhere
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No explicit finding of past persecution
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Applications dismissed except for complicity determination
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed applications except complicity finding quashed
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Officer Blouin's decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 108(4) exception for compelling reasons in cases of past persecution
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 108(4) not triggered due to absence of finding of past persecution

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged complicity in crimes against humanity during Sierra Leone civil war
Crimes.Outcome: Complicity determination quashed, application dismissed on other grounds
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Involvement with Civil Defense Unit during conflict
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, international human rights law
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Complicity finding set aside, application dismissed
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Credibility: Persecution claims not meeting 'appalling' or 'atrocious' threshold

Application_Facts: Applicant provided evidence of 1178 days of physical presence in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Met quantitative requirement (1178 days), but qualitative test improperly applied
Procedural_Issue: Improper application of qualitative test despite meeting quantitative threshold
Evidence_Used: Documentation proving 1178 days of physical presence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Citizenship Judge ignored reliable evidence of physical presence
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied by Citizenship Judge
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by another Citizenship Judge
Decision_Rationale: Judge erred by applying qualitative test when quantitative requirement was met; reliable evidence of physical presence was disregarded

Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in concluding that a viable internal flight alternative existed in Dhaka
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; RAD decision upheld
Credibility_Assessment: No credible threat from local persecutors in Dhaka due to limited resources and lack of interest outside Habiganj
Evidence_Type: Family's wealth, location-based risk assessment, feasibility of relocation
Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA relating to refugee protection and internal flight alternative
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution over ancestral property rights in Bangladesh
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No serious possibility of persecution in Dhaka; conditions not unreasonable for relocation
Application_Factor: Feasibility of relocation despite hardships due to family's financial means
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed; no basis for overturning RAD decision
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicants had significant absences from Canada; incomplete documentation including tax returns, health records, and bank statements with gaps
Residency_Compliance: Failed to accumulate at least 1,095 days of residence in Canada within the 1,460 days preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review process initiated under Federal Courts Act
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Incomplete documentation; gaps in records proving physical presence in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; deficiency in evidence rather than credibility found
Remedy_Sought: Granting of Canadian citizenship or remittal for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The citizenship judge reasonably concluded that the applicants did not meet the required residency threshold due to insufficient proof

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and sought exemption from deportation based on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Applicant not informed of concerns about marriage bona fides and denied opportunity to respond
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions in file not disclosed to applicant
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubts raised about marriage bona fides
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from s. 9(1) based on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Balance of probabilities should have been used
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Denial based on unsubstantiated doubts without procedural fairness

Crimes.Violation_Type: Alleged fraudulent marriage for immigration benefit
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant denied exemption from applying for landed immigrant status outside Canada due to alleged marriage fraud
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Compliant except for marriage legitimacy concern
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Yes, implied by doubts over marriage bona fides
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Applicant not informed of contradictions and not given chance to respond
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Internal memos and decision letter citing doubts
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to disclose specific contradictions to applicant
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Marriage deemed not bona fide based on undisclosed concerns
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision based on incorrect legal standard and lack of procedural fairness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged misrepresentation regarding marriage bona fides
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper application of standard of proof in assessing misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubts about marriage authenticity not properly assessed
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and internal assessment records
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Relevant provisions concerning misrepresentation in immigration applications
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant denied exemption due to doubts about marriage validity
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Standard of proof and procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Error: Use of criminal standard of proof in civil matter
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Balance of probabilities should have been applied
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correct legal standard and procedural fairness required on redetermination
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not explicitly found, but allegations of misrepresentation

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged immigration fraud through invalid marriage claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Wrong standard of proof and denial of procedural fairness in fraud assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Marriage bona fides questioned without proper disclosure
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Internal decision records and application documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Provisions related to fraud in immigration applications
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Denial of exemption due to suspected fraudulent marriage
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Standard of proof and right to respond
Crimes.Application_Error: Applied 'reasonable doubt' instead of 'balance of probabilities'
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Balance of probabilities is correct standard
Crimes.Application_Factor: Marital relationship as basis for immigration relief
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Legality and procedural fairness reviewed by court
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged but not proven; procedural flaws prevented fair assessment

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present for 621 days out of the required 1095 days in the four years preceding application.
Absence due to spousal support during husband's temporary work assignment abroad.
Prior to absence, applicant lived and worked in Canada, paid taxes, and established a home.
Residency_Compliance: Insufficient physical presence but maintained strong ties to Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to Federal Court - Trial Division following denial by Citizenship judge
Evidence_Used: Duration of physical presence in Canada
Proof of home establishment in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Citizenship judge failed to properly consider temporary nature of absence and ties to Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-year residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act with allowance for temporary absences
Decision_Rationale: Absence was temporary and justified by spousal support.
Applicant maintained significant ties to Canada.
Citizenship judge erred in failing to properly assess the temporary nature of the absence and the strength of the applicant's connections to Canada.
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship judge, Federal Court - Trial Division

Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration agent properly assessed the applicant's eligibility under the Federal Skilled Worker class
Governing_Law: Subsection 75(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Evidence_Type: Evidence of performance of NOC-listed duties
Legal_Provision: Subsection 75(2), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient evidence of meeting occupational requirements as per NOC description
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of reasoning in agent's decision
Assessment_Standard: Applicant must perform tasks described in NOC occupational descriptions and a substantial number of main duties
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
Application_Factor: Performance of duties as defined by NOC
Decision_Outcome: Case remanded for reconsideration by different agent
Authority: Federal Court (implied through judicial review jurisdiction)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations
Risk_Factor: Perceived complicity in crimes by the Peruvian army
Nature_of_Acts: Alleged involvement in acts contrary to UN principles
Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of evidence establishing personal involvement
Standard_of_Proof: Serious reasons must exist for considering involvement
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Decision overturned, remanded for new hearing
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged involvement in war crimes during service
Legal_Provision: Article 1F(a) and (c) of the Refugee Convention
Risk_Nature: Fear of persecution due to reporting drug trafficking

Risk_Factor: Perceived complicity in crimes by the Peruvian army
Nature_of_Acts: Alleged complicity in crimes against humanity
Key_Evidence_Issue: No specific findings linking applicant to crimes
Credibility_Factors: Lack of detailed or corroborating evidence
Standard_of_Proof: Serious reasons to believe involvement required

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Board's decision incorrect, remanded for new hearing
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity in crimes against humanity
Jurisdiction: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration matters
Risk_Factor: Personal risk due to reporting internal corruption
Risk_Nature: Threats from Peruvian army after reporting drug trafficking
Victim_Basis: Whistleblower targeted for exposing criminal activity

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's assessment of the objective basis of the applicant's claim
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible as a Catholic, but persecution claims doubted due to lack of evidence
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence showing Fujian Catholics could practice freely
Legal_Provision: Section 96 and Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution based on Roman Catholic faith
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence such as arrest warrant; general conditions for Catholics in Fujian
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Legal_Standard: Objective basis for fear of persecution
Application_Factor: Credibility of applicant, documentary country evidence
Decision_Outcome: Applicant not recognized as a Convention refugee
